George Harrison recorded the sitar introduction during take 3 in April 1966; it appeared again as an overdub onto take six – accompanied by the tabla, bass and fuzz guitar.



 George Harrison (centre) and Paul McCartney (right) at a sitar shop in New Delhi. 

George Harrison introduced much of the western world to the instrument in late 1965 on “Norwegian Wood (This Bird Has Flown),” influencing Brian Jones of The Rolling Stones to play the sitar on their May 1966 song “Paint it Black.”

Make love all day long
 Make love singing songs
 
 [Interlude]
 
 [Refrain 2]
 Make love all day long
 Make love singing songs

Mark Herstgaard, author of “A Day in the Life: The Music and Artistry of the Beatles” stated that these lines penned by Harrison were a “"response to the fleetingness of time was to affirm and celebrate life: ‘make love all day long / make love singing songs’”.

Love me while you can
 Before I’m a dead old man

Harrison talks a lot in the song about how brief life is, but it’s still a love song, and the attitude he conveys is a carpe diem type of attitude.
Life is short, so use your time wisely before it runs out.

There’s people standing round
 Who’ll screw you in the ground
 They’ll fill you in with all their sins you’ll see

The people Harrison is speaking about here are the people who are negative and judgmental. They will easily harass and nag you to the point you are grounded, never enjoying your own life. The line “They’ll fill you in with all their sins you’ll see” is Harrison indicating that these people may do the same things as you, but will still get at you for it.
But what you’ve got means such a lot to me
Harrison tells his love again that whatever she has is very important to him, not necessarily her body or her sexual qualities but her personality and her company.

A lifetime is so short
 A new one can’t be bought

The underlying message of the song is of the shortness of life and to enjoy what you have before it’s gone. The Beatles were popular during the 60’s when freedom of expression, ability, and love were important and as such many of their songs contained messages on living life to the fullest.

Each day just goes so fast
 I turn around, it’s past
 You don’t get time to hang a sign on me

Harrison is talking about the shortness of life and how every time he reflects on it, more of it has slipped by. The second verse is part of the Beatles mantra of not being placed in a box or a label. This is also an allusion to tombstones and their descriptions.
